Travel funds are requested to partially support approximately 13 graduate students and young faculty to participate in the 2014 AES Electrophoresis Society Annual Meeting will be held November 16-21, 2014 in Atlanta, GA.

The AES Electrophoresis Society Annual Meeting is an international meeting will involve participants from various sectors of the research community including academia, industry, and federal research laboratories. The 2014 AES Meetings offers a rich atmosphere for the presentation and exchange of ideas centered on the advancement of electrokinetic phenomena for applications in biotechnology, materials science, and separations science. The award will be used to facilitate increased student participation in the meeting. These students will receive additional training and take an active leadership role in the administration of the conference by helping to convene a subset of the technical sessions.

This meeting is expected to result in bolstered scientific interactions amongst AES members and the broader AIChE community. Students funded through this effort will co-author a journal article summarizing the meeting and serve as co-chairs for one of the technical sessions. This invaluable experience will bolster their academic networks and provide them with future career opportunities. Past AES Electrophoresis Society Meetings have led to postdoctoral job opportunities, collaborations, and faculty positions for the attendees. It is anticipated that this year's meeting will achieve similar results but with a stronger emphasis on student engagement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2014 AES Electrophoresis Society Annual Meeting was held November 16-21, 2014 in Atlanta, GA.  This international meeting involved participants from various sectors of the research community including academia, industry, and federal research laboratories.  The 2014 AES Meetings offered a rich atmosphere for the presentation and exchange of ideas centered on the advancement of electrokinetic phenomena for applications in biotechnology, materials science, and separations science.

The 2014 AES Electrophoresis Society Meeting had several attributes designed to bolster student engagement including training workshops on the first day of the meeting, an interactive poster session, and a Lunch with Leaders program to facilitate student/faculty interaction. The meeting also included several opportunities for informal interaction including a networking event and a closing banquet.

Intellectual Merit

The AES Electrophoresis Society Annual Meeting is the leading venue for experts from academia and industry exploring electrokinetic phenomena and their application in diverse fields ranging from materials assembly to DNA separation.  The 2014 meeting was co-chaired by Cullen R. Buie (Massachusetts Institute of Technology) and Rodrigo Martinez-Duarte (Clemson University). The AES Electrophoresis Society Annual Meeting is a unique gathering as it seamlessly integrates scientists working on both the fundaments and applications of electrokinetic phenomena. There were ten technical sessions in addition to a poster session, a plenary session, and an awards session. The five plenary talks were given by a diverse group of scholars at various stages of their careers.

Broader Impacts

Past AES Electrophoresis Society Meetings have led to postdoctoral job opportunities, collaborations, and faculty positions for the attendees. It is anticipated that the 2014 meeting will achieve similar results but with a stronger emphasis on student engagement.

Overall, the 2014 AES Annual Meeting was a huge success. The funding provided by NSF allowed for 15 students from a wide array of universities across the United States to attend the meeting. In a unique wrinkle, the student attendees had the opportunity to co-chair technical sessions throughout the meeting alongside faculty. This was a valuable experience and relevant training for those of them considering academic careers. Additionaly, there was a mentoring event at the meeting in which established faculty shared lunch with the students. The students were given the opportunity to ask questions about faculty life and learn what they need to do in order to obtain an academic position. The feedback from the students on this event was overwhelmingly positive.
